awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: Building Sophisticated Services with Programmable Anonymity Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project designs and implements programmable system elements to be run within the anonymity networks, such as Tor (The Onion Routing network). The central idea is that users can inject new code into the network that is then run within a protected execution environment. The motivation is to enable the creation of new and significantly enhanced anonymity services, such as content distribution networks, of use in today's and future anonymity networks. The project carries potential to demonstrate that an anonymity communication network, such as today's Tor network, could deliver a much larger range of services that could greatly enhance the potential range of offerings over secure, anonymous networks, motivating further developments.

The proposed research has four main and original thrusts: (1) Programmable Tor middleboxes,
(2) Censorship-resistant hidden services, (3) Hidden-services-based content distribution network (CDN), (4) Decentralized anonymous credentials. Much thought and development will also go into the applications that can be built upon the proposed functionalities, and as a result, if successful, the end possibilities are expected to be transformative. The training obtained by students during the investigation spanning across cryptography, secure computation, and anonymized communication networks are expected to result in a cohort with a distinctive, important and useful set of skills.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Anonymity systems are critical in achieving free, open communication on today’s Internet. In particular, Tor, a popular peer-to-peer anonymous system, has become a staple in resisting online censorship by rogue nations and allowing journalists to safely communicate with sources world-wide.  However, there is a surprisingly narrow set of services that Tor is able to support in a robust fashion.

In this joint project between Purdue University and the University of Maryland, we have endeavored to develop programmable anonymity networks—extensions of Tor that allow users to install and run small snippets of code on Tor routers—and use them to build more sophisticated, more secure anonymous services.  We used a combination of secure hardware (e.g., Intel’s SGX), cryptography, and systems design to develop programmable Tor middleboxes: programmable middleboxes akin to network function virtualization in today’s software-defined networks.  We also explored applications built on top of Tor, including new defenses against website fingerprinting and traffic correlation attacks, as well as novel ways to scale up hidden services and evade censorship.

To achieve these results, we developed several enabling technologies, including decentralized anonymous credentials and a new architectural primitive we call “conclaves” (short for “containers of enclaves”). Conclaves make it straightforward to deploy multi-process, scalable, legacy applications within trusted execution environments like Intel SGX. Using conclaves, we developed Phoenix, content delivery network (CDN) that does not require any access to customers’ keys, yet is still able to apply web application firewalls, scalability, multitenancy, and geographic distribution. Notably, Phoenix works without requiring any modifications to legacy web-hosting software.

We also extensively studied one of the primary threats to anonymity systems: nation-state censors. We developed Geneva, a novel AI-based technique that automatically discovers ways to evade nation-state censors, and we used Geneva’s findings to gain unprecedented insight into how censors operate and how they can be circumvented. Geneva has discovered over 80 circumvention strategies that clients inside censoring regimes can use to achieve unhindered communication, and Geneva discovered the first-ever “server-side” evasion strategies, which require no client-side software whatsoever. Geneva also discovered new ways that censorship infrastructure can be weaponized, showing that censoring regimes pose a greater threat to the security of the Internet than previously thought. Geneva’s findings helped inform our design and implementation of Bento and its various functions.

The central effort unifying our various avenues of research is an architecture we call Bento. Bento runs on top of Tor, and provides the mechanisms and execution environments for safely deploying and running programmable functions in the Tor network. Bento incorporates our work on conclaves, anonymous credentials, and censorship circumvention. Ultimately, Bento shows that programmable anonymity networks can be a powerful, safe, and efficient way to achieve greater security and anonymity.

Throughout all aspects of this project, we have sought to broaden undergraduate participation in computer science research, especially among women and BIPOC students. We have run various outreach efforts—including research hackathons, a Computer Science Honors program, and programs with high school women—that have collectively introduced hundreds of women and BIPOC students to research. Additionally, the PIs have personally advised dozens of undergraduate students throughout the life of this project, many of which have continued onto graduate studies.
